context: Arson, one of the toughest crimes to solve.  That’s why, if you do catch an arsonist, the death penalty is appropriate.  Remember, in most instances, arsonists that are caught set fires previously, just didn’t get caught.

replies.context: The first step is determining what caused the fire.  It can be accidental or intentional, but many times a firm call is not practical, so it's listed as undetermined.  Proving the who set the fire intentionally is the next step.  Both steps are hampered by the fact that 110PSI water and other firefighting efforts go a long way to wiping evidence from the point of origin.  Besides, if the ship was a fire waiting to happen, a cigarette or matchbook would be all you need and that's not a lot of evidence to work with.

replies.context: I spent 38+ years, overhauling Aircraft Carriers. There was a Shipboard or Dry Dock fire almost daily. Ships Force and Shipyard FD would both respond. Fires were usually caused by grinding, welding, brazing, or careless smoking. Rarely did the fire last more than 10 minutes, and even more rarely, did it result in any casualties. It goes with the job.
